The Highlights
Visual style: Minimalist, with Shinbo Akiyuki written all over it.
Dialogue: Witty, fast and engaging.
Romance: Slow and compelling.
Ending: Incomplete.
Senjogahara Hitagi: Sublime.
Shinbo Akiyuki and Nishio Ishin are a match made in heaven. Any veteran of Shaft‘s works (Sayonara Zetsubou Sensei, Maria Holic, Hidamari Sketch) should be familiar with Shinbo‘s quirky and unique visual style, often relying on clever use of typography and colors to abstractly represent characters and situations. While this approach may seem slightly inappropriate for some other anime he’s produced (and certainly, it often seems that Shinbo tries a little too hard to indiscriminately jam his visual style down viewers’ throats), it fits perfectlywith Bakemonogatari. The original light novel, penned by Nishio Ishin, features rapid-fire dialogue and constant wordplay, the perfect environment for Shinbo to wreak visual havoc. The words coming out of characters’ mouths and the text being displayed on screen are often two different interpretations of the same conversation. Bakemonogatari is a symphony of typography and color. Most visual elements are stripped down to their bare essentials: backgrounds are monochromatic, details are eschewed for simple geometric shapes, flashy animation is replaced by paper cutouts and black-and-white photographs. The show leaves much to the imagination of its viewers, and refrains from spoon-feeding viewers small morsels of plot.\n\n
In contrast the simple minimalism of the background, the show’s characters are exquisite. Visually, they are stunning. Elegant and colorful, they seem to glow – adding vibrance to the monochromatic and geometrical world around them. Their radiance indicates to the audience that they are Bakemonogatari.\n\n
And indeed, they are. Senjogahara Hitagi, the heroine of the show, is stunning. Self-deprecating, witty and bitingly sarcastic, she is one of the most unique and memorable characters to come out of anime in recent years. The interplay between her and Araragi, the show’s protagonist, is an absolute delight to watch. The show is theirs – in its purest form, Bakemonogatari is a love story between Araragi and Senjogahara. Their love is free of overly dramatic confessions and poorly made Valentine’s Day chocolate. Much is left unsaid between them, which makes their relationship so much more compelling and realistic.\n\n
Each of the show’s five arcs explores a specific aspect of their relationship: contact, confession, injury, jealousy, infidelity. Superficially, Bakemonogatari seems like five separate stories about supernatural phenomena. Yet, beneath the surface, Araragi and Senjogahara’s relationship always plays a role throughout the entirety of the series, and links the five unrelated stories together. Even when Senjogahara isn’t on screen, her presence and influence upon Araragi can be felt. Their relationship is marked by a quiet, unbreakable bond of trust, forged and developed through shared trials and tribulations. Senjogahara begins the show a cold, bitter and angry girl, harboring murderous malevolence towards Araragi. Throughout the course of Bakemonogatari‘s story, she slowly warms to him, developing an unspoken confidence in him which eventually blossoms into an unconditional and passionate love. Her relationship with Araragi is marked by mutual benefit and reciprocity – unlike most anime heroines, Senjogahara never becomes a subservient doormat for Araragi to step on.\n\n
The supporting cast in Bakemonogatari truly supports the main characters. They are many and varied: classmates, former lovers, childhood friends, strangers wandering the streets – but they all strengthen the story’s main narrative. At the same time, Bakemonogatari‘s mysteries are filled with imagination and are compelling and solid short stories in their own right. The fast pace of action helps keep viewers engaged and interested in every new episode while Araragi and Senjogahara’s romance is developed slowly, at a comfortable and realistic speed.\n\n
Unfortunately, the show’s ending left much to be desired. It felt extremely underwhelming compared to the brilliance which marked the rest of the series. Much hand-waving went on during the final few episodes, and the final resolution to the last arc reeked of deus ex machina. Few things were explained, and the show wrapped up without much conclusion. After fourteen episodes of top-notch storytelling, it honestly felt like SHAFT decided to take it easy. Regrettably, the ending of Bakemonogatari is the only thing which separates this show from perfection.\n\n
Still, Bakemonogatari is a tour de force of storytelling and visual style. The character development is sublime, and the main narrative is captivating. Undoubtedly one of the greatest series to come out of Japan in the last five years, Bakemonogatari will be remembered for years to come as an example of excellence in the the minds of thousands of fans.

IMPORTANT NOTE: If you wish to watch Bakemonogatari, it is on Crunchyroll, but only 12 out of the 15 episodes are available. The original TV run comprised of only 12 episodes and was actually quite conclusive in certain respects, but the remaining three episodes were released on the web over the following year. For those last three episodes, I recommend searching for them on Kissanime.to, or other anime streaming sites of the like nature. You will have to turn off AdBlock, so be mindful of popup ads, but it is worth it. Enjoy the review. 
Anyone who has studied film has probably heard of theFrench New Wave (La Nouvelle Vague), a movement of French filmmakers breaking off from traditional Hollywood filmmaking to produce their own, low budget, artistic works. The Nouvelle Vague was highlighted by films that compensated for their low budgets with inventive camerawork that changed a story could be conveyed through jump cuts and excessive environmental imagery. Characters would foreshadow events, break the fourth wall, and display a sentient knowledge of their existence as fictional characters, accompanied with extensive knowledge of the genre they inhabit. 


Bakemonogatari is the animated equivalent of the French New Wave. It is an artistic overdose of beautiful imagery and metaphysical commentary and even having lacked the analytical mind to truly grasp the show’s brilliance when I first watched it, I kept watching simply because it was so alien to me that I had to delve deeper. Bakemonogatari is the story of Koyomi Araragi, a young man living in a small, normal provincial town in Japan, but who’s personal life is far from ordinary. Due to a dark series of events alluded to in the opening minutes of the first episode, Araragi is half vampire, a state upon which he was made by a powerful vampire who for reasons unknown to the audience, is now reduced to the form of a young girl, without the ability to speak. Her caretaker is Meme Oshino, a foreign man in a Hawaiian shirt with an encyclopedic knowledge of the supernatural. Araragi is acquaintances with Oshino, as Araragi, as if cursed, tends to attract all manner of supernatural occurrences to him. 


Over the course of 15 episodes, Araragi encounters five young women who are in some way plagued by supernatural spirits and, being a good samaritan, works to try and save them from the apparitions plaguing them. The first girl, Hitagi Senjougahara, is plagued by an apparition that feeds on trauma in her family’s past. The second, Mayoi Hachikuji, is a young girl on her way to her mother’s house but due to some supernatural occurrence, is unable to make her way out of the city. Next is Suruga Kanbaru, Araragi’s underclassman. After coming in contact with the cursed limb of a monkey, her arm is transformed into that of a beast. The arm will take control at times and make Kanbaru go on violent sprees against the main character. Next, we have Nadeko Sengoku, a friend of Araragi’s younger sisters who’s life is threatened by a snake-like apparition that leaves snakeskin marks along her body. Finally, there is Tsubasa Hanekawa, Araragi’s best friend (and arguably best girl). Her apparition introduces a Jekyll and Hyde element to the story as she becomes a completely different person at night and a very violent person at that. The apparitions are seemingly random in symptom but all appear to the girls as animals. A crab, a snail, a monkey, a snake, and finally, a cat. 


Araragi is an interesting protagonist because he is always trying to help people and this is both his greatest strength and his main weakness. It is a weakness that is at the heart of Bakemonogatari’s thematic hooks. Araragi wants to help these women and whether it is because of his admittedly childish sexual attraction or because of his innate kindness towards others, he goes through a shit ton of pain and agony and he is only able to survive torture after grueling torture because his vampiric abilities keep him from dying. This is a show about selflessness. It proposes that sometimes you cannot help everyone and that by succumbing to pain to help other people, you only make everyone else hurt. This is made more poignant by Araragi’s relationship with Senjougahara, who slowly becomes more intimate with him throughout the series. This in turn further strengthens Araragi’s struggle with whether or not to help people. 


The three pillars of Bakemonogatari are visuals, dialogue, and characters. Before addressing the leading ladies, we have to discuss Meme Oshino and Shinobu, as their parts are significantly smaller than that of the rest of the cast in this first season. Oshino is as laid back as they come. He exists primarily to give advice to Araragi about the supernatural threats plaguing each of the girls. Much like Araragi, he wants to help, but his clients need to be willing to exert a significant amount of effort on their own end, as well as compensation. Shinobu, on the other hand, doesn't have a lot of development, but it is clear that she and Araragi have a past and that he feels like he owes her in a way. This in a way connects to his impulse to help people. As for the rest of the cast, the ladies of Bakemonogatari steal the show. Senjougahara is one of my favorite female characters. She is disarmingly commanding of attention, always saying exactly what she is thinking. She is sociopathic to a level only rivaled by that of Benedict Cumberbatch’s portrayal of Sherlock. Her chemistry with Araragi leads to some of the most entertaining moments of the series. Similarily, Kanbaru has great chemistry with Araragi, but more because she is always challenging Araragi’s sexuality, whereas Senjougahara is challenging Araragi’s logic and at times, his decency. Hachikuji and Sengoku are both on the younger side, Hachikuji being 11 and Sengoku being 13. Hachikuji is energetic and playful, very confident in herself. Despite this, she can also be quite mature when listening to others’ problems- especially Araragi’s. In contrast, Sengoku is very shy and timid, with a naive crush on Araragi, to the point of addressing him the same formality as that of an elder brother.  

Whereas Hachikuji is deterred by Araragi’s jokingly pedophilic impulses in response to her cuteness, Sengoku demands that sort of attention, making her both adorable, but at the same time robbing her of any true character. Thankfully this lack of character pandering to the lowest denominator is addressed in later seasons and if you aren’t overly sensitive to this type of characterization, you will appreciate how adorable she is. Finally, there is Hanekawa. Tsubasa Hanekawa is a genius. She is deductive, insightful, and can see right through Araragi. I’m not sure there has ever been a single lie that has slipped by her from Araragi. In addition, she is disarmingly humble. Araragi will tell her that she knows everything, and Hanekawa will respond- every time- with her trademark phrase, “I don’t know everything. I only know what I know.” She is an angelic, bespectacled exposition machine that never ceases to have faith in her friends, and that makes her, like many of the characters in Monogatari, inherently awesome. 


It should be noted that for all the praise I give the show for its characters, there is plenty of fan service. Fan service is something that deters many people from watching anime. Now I’m no woman, so I won’t pretend to understand how a female viewer feels about the portrayal of characters. What I can do is ask “did the sexualization serve a purpose?” Secondly, I can ask “did the sexualization make the character less respectable?” Pertaining to the first question, I’d say that there are only a few times when the fanservice served no purpose. As for the second question, the fanservice never resulted in me respecting the characters less. The sexualization was either meant as a joke, to illustrate some meta-commentary (arguably), or possibly the most relatable reason for me, because the artists just wanted to show off how beautiful their character designs are. 


Studio Shaft is infamous for creating visually striking shows despite low budgets. The entire Monogatari series is a modern art piece in motion. The environments are often populated by minimalistic structures. The focal points of shots are accentuated by the very good use of primary colors. Whenever an anime displays very experimental, unusual, or trippy animation, people call it “pulling a Shaft”, a tongue in cheek phrase referring to studios echoing the works of Studio shaft and there is a bizarre honor to that. Shaft has pioneered an animation style of its own, which itself was an homage to the French New Wave. I could make an entire post about all the things I absolutely love about Monogatari’s visuals. And the best thing is that the show got even better over time. When the show aired on TV, there were some scenes that were not finished. But when the Blu-rays were released? It was phenomenal. However, good luck getting any entry in the Monogatari series for a reasonable price. Aniplex appears to derive pleasure from pilfering our wallets of over $100 just for 15 episodes because they decided to add a bunch of art books that still can’t make that price make sense. 

Bakemonogatari is a beautiful collection of stories about helping out friends and lovers in need that is accentuated by masterful dialogue and a strong visual presence. It all culminates in an indulgent, thoughtful, and gratifying conclusion to a show that will draw in many with titillation, only to surprise you with pure art.

What blistering pace. Time was not wasted this weekend on this piece. The only word I can use to describe this anime is 'cool'. A real cool show. It is marathon-worthy. I got 'bang-for-buck' with each episode, and really appreciated the fan service as well.
The story moves fast and rides professionally on the vehicle that was the art, soundtrack and direction all the way to the end. 
I'm a little picky with art lately but this was right up my alley. The clean drawings were a perfect match for the great characters. 
This was a fun show to watch and I was left wanting toknow more. I wanted to see more of the world created for those characters.\n\n
I enjoyed the experience of being surprised by the little things inside this show. It was so fun to watch- 2 hours sleep before work was worth it.\n\n
The story is simple, and simple works best in this case. I like that.\n\n
Check it out.

Bakemonogatari is a rather interesting piece, it is based on one of the older works of Nisio Isin, and it shows. To describe Bakemonogatari in one word, it would be unpolished. It's all there: amazing characters, witty dialogue, good story. But it all comes too unpolished to my tastes.
The story, while it has amazing moments (and characters), is unfortunately plagued by visual novel-like interactions, where Araragi just goes from one character to another, from one location to another, talking with characters and obtaining info. This making Bakemonogatari a rather tiring watch, as you haveepisodes where nothing happens, and you just have Araragi traveling around the city talking with his harem.\n\n
However, when it wants to get gud, it does get gud. My favorite episode of Bakemonogatari is for sure the last one: it is a perfect balance of dialogue and action, it has lots of dialogue but that's not just it, it has action, reveal and visual orgasm, the 20 minutes go by flying.\n\n
Now for technical aspects! The art. While the art in Monogatari is surely creative and engaging to look at, it has several minor flaws (fixed on the BDs) and several OTHER AWFULLY BAD PROPORTION FLAWS, on later seasons, this is fixed and the art gets MUCH better, but on Bake, these flaws make it just impossible to give something other than 8/10.\n\n
The songs are not really that good, it has some gems (ED, OP 1 and OP 4) and the background is nice (it's recognizeable and works to complement the scenes) but I feel like it could be replaced at any time and I woudn't miss it.\n\n
Overall, I give Bakemonogatari a score of 7.5/10.

If you enjoy a story with a quirky style of witty references than Bakemonogatari is perfect for you. However, if this is your first monogatari series and you are watching it based on people telling you how good it was, then prepare to be confused. The monogatari series has an interesting take on oddities such as vampires, snakes etc. and is very familiar to the shinto religion which played a key role in asia's spiritual advancement. The art style is very bland, yet exquisitely beautiful (you'll see what I mean). This is actual one of the most well-drawn anime I have ever seen. As faras characters go the story is too deep to give them depth. The only character that possesses a sense of depth is Hanekawa and her ignored love. Overall I rate it as a good series, but this is boosted to a very good series by it's clever references and stunning visuals.

Okay, ill just go straight to the point. Bakemonogatari is an anime that breaks the NORM, actually it destroys the norm. Bakemonogatari is a show that is so nice to see because it is unique, showing a completely different perspective of anime.
The show consists of a few story arch that spawn as the protagonist life progresses. Meaning that our main character story and the story arch intertwine at key moments of the story. Without giving away much, the story is  and interesting. And will certainly be enjoyed by more critical anime viewers. This is a very dialogue driven story so don't expect any actionsegments at all.


The art is different, which is something one will notice right at the start. There is a big use of words especially at the beginning of each episode. Overall the art is something that I don't often see but it's absolutely effective.


The characters are fantastic, each with their little problems. The way the characters converse with one another is enjoyable to hear and is a breath of fresh air from the majority of anime. Essentially character interactions can either be realistic or extremely strange. Which makes the show more interesting to watch. Characters are a key part of this series and you will get to understand why soon. 


I loved this anime. It's effective but not by conventional means. Bakemonogatari is definitely worth a watch for someone who wants something different.

If Quentin Tarantino ever decided to make an anime, odds are it would be very much like Bakemonogatari. Just like Pulp Fiction, Bakemonogatari mixes great characters and large chunks of well acted everyday-dialogue, with sudden bursts of ultra violence. A combination that is simply excellent.
Truth be told, though, the story itself isn't all that great. It's arc-based (I'm not a fan of obvious arcs in general) and very harem like, as Koyomi Araragi soon rounds up his own ragtag team of beautiful school girl misfits of varying ages. They all have personal problems of a more supernatural nature, and Araragi is simply too considerate tolet them be.


Bakemonogatari's brightest stars are its clear cut visuals and music, but also the way it simply refuses to use common storytelling techniques to deliver its narrative. The bright colors and the original camera work makes for a very interesting piece of viewing, and even though some dialogue drags on a bit too long, the series is still a joy to watch, frame to frame.


Bakemonogatari is simply a must watch for every anime fan. It's the closest thing to pure art I've seen on a screen for a long time.

It's a different experience, a static one I would say. Here you will experience words, conversations, long conversations. If you are a fan of pure action, don't watch, it's almost without it.
We meet Araragi-kun (Araragi being oh oh oh in japanese) which was recently attacked by a vampire, so now he is a vampire in in 1/8th, so then he meets a girl that weights 1 kilogram and keeps school equipment inside her body, and then he meets a snail girl, which would follow him everywhere.
YES THAT IS BAKEMONOGATARI, A ghoststory.
It's really hard to describe what this anime represents. Im gonna try to do it,the best I can.

You would hear simple conversations, they might last for half of a episode. Simple subjects are moved there. Those very conversations would act as snowballs, making a simple subject a big matter, turning it around so the point of the whole conversation would flip around, to be something else. It's crazy how writers wrote the script for it, they are geniuses.

But if I was to explain the plot in a easy way. It's a exceptional story, of a group of young people being possesed by different "beings", which you metaphorically read as - problems.

It's weird guys, it's just very weird.


VIBE:

Vibe makes this whole thing a good thing. It's a anime where they would use a lot of dialogues, meaning the voiceacting must be good. Well because listening to voices without good visual background is not as entertainting, they would throw some nice animations there.

First of all what you will experience is being overwhelmed. It will be difficult to comprehend what are they even talking about, to finally realize that it is simple. And that is the vibe, it's a big f-ing mystery. The characters and their development won't reveal anything, you will have to read through the lines and discover what exactly is going on.

It's a game of metaphors. 


ART STYLE:

They wanted to make the artstyle special. And yeah it is. I personally call it squarey, the people and props around have a certain square shape. it is weird, but makes good cooperation with everything else.

The other thing I like about the art style is that they would change the color scheme based on who is the main person in the scene, more pink there you go it's there. More yellow, which Araragi-san uses, well here you go, red one? Oh yeah the other character uses it.

I also love how they would insanely use props in the series, putting a lot of them in one place, or not placing a single one. Background is truly a mystery in this anime.


MUSIC/VOICEACTING:

Can't really talk about music, it is faint, the main focus is on voiceacting. 

Voiceacting had to be the main thing here, it is the most important element in the series. So yeah all of the voices are chose wisely, every single one of them had to sound original, and it had to be pleasant. I think they managed to do that.


STORYLINE:

Well it's really hard to follow the story line in this anime. Especially when so much talking happens. But basically it's nice, yet very simple. Araragi would stumble upon various problems of other people, trying to help them with his knowledge, or knowledge of someone elses. That way he develops and makes new connections.

There is also a good chunk of romance in it, a pretty nice one. I would call it weirdly-platonic.


CONCLUSION:

Well in conclusion, I recommend it to people that are into reflection, and maybe a chill out. It's a original concept with a lot of work put into it, good work to be honest. It's hard to comprehend, but fun.

Bakemonogatari  review
Bakemonogatari is the preparation stage where our  characters  make their debut  using a unique animation art style made by Shaft studio and the writing style of Nisio Isin for the plot and story.
Bakemonogatari is divided in many story arcs , each arc focuses on a different character  solving their problems symbolized by the “aberrations” with the help of our main character Araragi and the masterfully use of the dialogue for the characterization and plot. Each arc is connected and contribute for the further development of the  relationship between Araragi and Senjougahara which is the main focus of theplot and story in Bakemonogatari.


Bakemonogatari uses each subtle detail from the dialogue lines to evidentiate  the characters traits and speech habits. To make it more realistic for the viewer the anime uses a unique camera angle to portray each character’s insight on the situation or the other person  during a conversation. 


The dialogue is the essence for the characterization and presentation of the characters in Bake.We have Senjougahara  the cynical and cruel tsundere who says harsh words to Araragi but caring for him deep in her heart. Araragi who is a typical generic male  character but his actions and influence on other characters contribute a lot for the story and plot. Taking his time to speak with each girl and understand their problems we found out more about his traits and background story. Bake gives importance to his minor characters and uses them for the plot and the characterization of the main characters Araragi and Senjougahara.


In each arc , the anime manages to portray aspects from the human drama and human nature. For example the Hitagi crab and Lost Snail arc portrays the disconnected relationship between children and parents from our modern society, the linger of a child to be with his mother and the harsh law that forbids him. It signals a warning about the fraud of the cults and the consequences that lead in destroying families and the accidents involving children in our modern world.


The other arcs take a approach on the human mind and heart portraying jealousy ,hatred ,  struggle to find a place where you belong , responsibility ,love, fear, cowardness and finally the weakness inside our mind and heart. All is done with the help of the dialogue , art animation and symbolic animal  “aberrations” specific for each character. 


In conclusion Bakemonogatari is just one piece of the puzzle that makes the greater image called Monogatari series .It manages to use his characters and plot to deliver a good play using subtle details and dialogue for characterization , fanservice for the viewer but also using it properly in the plot and story , good ost and unique art style. A harem with generic characters that have so much to offer for plot and story granting entertainment for the viewer.


Overall 9/10

This would be a good anime. It really would, if it focused more on the cool story. 
It's like a partial SoL where your typical NEET gets all the girls for no reason and all the main characters aside from the NEET are hot girls who fall in love with him. Even a lesbian at one point more or less. Like, really?
It also tries too hard to be artistic. It's full of text that disappears so fast you'd need to advance frame by frame to read it, weird art where for no reason the people will like, turn into food or something random. Not partof a mood or playful scene or anything, it'll just be random. Flashy annoying art, art that's hard to figure out what the hell is going on, etc.\n
Otherwise it has a very nice story to it... which you come into part way through and have to piece together what happened before then... and then it ends leaving you still wanting more.\n\n
It's worth watching despite my harsh review, but it's nothing special. I recommend this for either people who like lots of fanservice lovey dovey stuff, and for anime fans that have watched all the good animes already.

-Spoilers ahead, you have been warned-
The Monogatari series is about a self proclaimed loner that in his own words "has no friends" named Koyomi Araragi. Araragi is a former vampire, to which is a category of "Oddity" in the series, but still has lingering side effects after being cured such as greatly increased healing and strength. In an ironic twist, Araragi finds himself surrounded by a large cast of girls. The Monogatari series IS a harem, with Araragi's growing relationships with the girls one of the main points sold along with the cast's working knowledge of the supernatural.
 Bakemonogatari is broken up into five characterarcs centered around a particular girl with each arc named after said girl: Hitagi Crab, Mayoi Snail, Suruga Monkey, Nadeko Snake and Tsubasa Cat in that order. The rest of the series follows this trend with only a few rare exceptions where the arc is named after Araragi, such as Koyomi Vamp. 


The first girl introduced in Bakemonogatari is named Hitagi Senjougahara, who Araragi catches after she slips on a banana peel, yes seriously, and falls down a flight of spiraling stairs in their shared high school. He immediately finds out that she weighs next to nothing when he catches her. She proceeds to threaten him with a stapler to not tell anyone about her condition. After she walks off, he decides to run after her and offer her his help. He takes her to the very same specialist in Oddities that helped cure his own vampirism, Meme Oshino. After a fee of 100,000 yen, a bit of exposition and some praying to a minor god, the problem is solved and Senjougahara gets her weight back. 


The Monogatari series is definitely not for everyone; the series is famous for being weird, and how much the characters like to talk. While both are true, if you enjoy witty dialogue and wordplay, you won't find any issue watching this series. I personally love the Monogatari series with one of my favorite characters ever, a sassy vampire loli obsessed with donuts named Shinobu, coming from Bakemonogatari. There are few action scenes, but the character interactions are what really make Bakemonogatari and the whole series going forward shine.

I've watched a fair bit of the Monogatari series now, so I'm coming back to this to give it a review.
First off, Bakemonogatari is the worst of the Monogatari series that I've watched. There's 3 episodes out of it that I like. Episodes 1&2, and 12. The rest of the episodes can die in a fire. Also, the last three episodes have to be hunted down or pirated or whatever. I'm so disinterested in that. So I dropped the series. I don't need to listen to more speeches from Lars Ulrich about how Napster is oppressing Metallica for one thing.
Once, as a child, I gotpoison ivy all over my body. I had horrible blisters all over my body. It was still a better experience than watching Bakemonogatari. My advice would be to watch the three episodes that I outlined. Then go to pornhub to find the rest of the Monogatari experience. Although, if you're into child porn, I'm going to distance myself from you, but that's what you can expect from this show in the relationship between the lead Koyomi Araragi and the youngest victim of his harem, Mayoi Hachikuji. I think she's like 11, or something, and every time Araragi sees her, he puts on his rape face and tries to molest her. That's a true story, by the way. I found that relationship to be in poor taste and offensive. Even the Japanese have to have boundaries.\n\n
If, however, you are the type that likes child porn and watching paint dry, then Bakemonogatari is the right show for you.

STORY - 6
ART - 6
SOUND - 7
CHARACTER - 7
ENJOYMENT - 6
Bakemonogatari is the first anime of the Monogatari Series that I've watched. I'm looking forward to what will come next as the anime has this unique atmosphere that made watching it quite enjoyable.
The anime started out confusing at first, there weren't really any clear storyline. You follow a boy who survived a vampire attack as he tried to solve supernatural problems of five girls on their own arc. The simplicity of the entire thing is a good thing, you see the characters develop and interact with each other in an interesting way. Comedy was prettyaverage, romance different from other anime and all in all, it was fun to see the characters. As the story was mainly dialogue-driven, it may not suit everyone. It's fast-paced and sometimes the dialogue was boring and unrelated to the point where your mind wanders of elsewhere. But when it was good, the dialogue is thought-provoking, giving off interesting information about the supernatural of this anime.\n\n
The story is backed by the abstract and surrealistic art style. The minimalistic feel suited Bakemonogatari. Animation was pretty fluid most of the time but it's really good at action scenes. There was a lot of symbolism used and for me, a lot of it was difficult to grasp but that's generally not a bad thing because the whole weirdness of it all did engage my brain. The sound in this anime didn't really stand out for me and it was not distracting. Voice acting of each characters was done well, suited to their personality. I enjoyed listening to the opening songs but the ending song takes the icing on the cake, especially after I found out the meaning behind supercell's beautiful song.\n\n
Overall, Bakemonogatari was enjoyable to watch. The anime is unique to others and that's what captivated me as I watched each episode. The story was simple and you get to enjoy the characters more. Some parts did felt useless to watch which did kind of drag on. What was the strong point of this anime? Definitely the character interactions and development.

Ah, Bakemonogatari. An anime which I, in my first immersion into the world of Japanese animation, never really understood. I liked it, don't get me wrong, it was - and is - a super stylish anime that makes for great AMVs, but other than that I didn't really get it and the hype arround it. So while writing this review of my rewatch after a long ass time, I realised how amazing an anime it really is.
Story: 8/10
At first Bakemonogatari seems to share some shounen-aspects; gorgeous and cute women surround a nice but average highschooler who helps them in one way or another. That's whenthe very interesting part kicks in. The main character, Araragi Koyomi, is part vampire (around 10%) and is well connected to some sort of spiritualist named Oshino Meme. Together, they help those girls with their own supernatural troubles. It still sounds pretty basic, but the way the story is told and narrated is interesting. Each of the parts of the story (titled, for example, Hitagi snail) is both an enclosed story and a part of the overarching story. The cool thing aboput the way the story is told is that characters of an already done story have an impact on later episodes or have single episodes focused on them even though their own tale is already told. I hope that makes sense. Also, the aforementioned harem effect never really kicks in which was, admittedly, a bit unexpected when I watched it the first time.


Art & Sound: 20/20

Perfect scores. The artstyle is experimental and gorgeous to look at, especially the character designs are fantastic. I know that SHAFT got shafted (heh) a lot for the copious amount of detailled shots focused on a character's eyes or our mouth which reduced the need to animate a whole body or scene, but I loved that. I was quite amazed at how smoothly and realistic stuff like twitchy eyes or speaking mouths were animated. The colour palette used on the characters was also surprisingly subdued for an anime; no garish pink or icy blue hair, no over the top clothing. The worst offender in the "this is not realistic!" department was Shinobu with orange eyes and that weird helmet with goggles on top. 

The rest of the animation was minimalistic. a lot of simple colours and repeated patterns, for example the bike parking lot in front of Koyomi's high school. It also often is a weird mxi between what looks like to be 3D rendered, cut from white paper and actual photographies. In a couple of one word attributes, I'd describe Bakemonogatari's visuals as: daring, dazzling, bizarre, experimental (as noted above) and recognizable. The last one is especially true cause as far as I know, only the Monogatari-series looks like the Monogatari-series. 

As for the sound, it was just perfection. Kimi No Shiranai Monogatari, the series ending, is by FAR and away my favorite ending ever. Period. ESPECIALLY after Episode 11, I think (can't tell why cause I try to keep this spoiler free). Something Bakemonogatari also does is change the opening with each arc. Of those openings, I love both Staple Staple (the first) and Sugar Sweet Nightmare (the fifth) the most. Not only is it really good pop/poprock, the lyrics also fit the character arcs pretty well. OTher than that, the soundtrack is great at increasing or erasing the tension of a situation, spice up the comedy and whatnot. On to the last point about sound, the voice actors are equally amazing, their voices fit the characters to a T. Special mentions go to Yui Horie (Hanekawa) and Chiwa Saito (Senjougarhara; I already talked highly of her in my PMMM review). Art-and soundwise, Bakemonogatari is a masterpiece.


Characters: 8/10 

My only real criticism is that in a 15 episode anime, we have 7 prominent characters and Shinobu who is sorta there. That makes eight characters for a rather short show. Compared to Madoka, those eight characters don't really have the time to develop. That being said, I like every character cause all of their issues which weigh them down are sorta relatable, in a sense. Sure, stuff like Nadeko's small snake problem is supernatural, but the reason why she has that problem in the first place is very human and, to a degree, understandable. My favorite character, by the way, is Suruga. Her arc is pretty damn cool, her design is great, her VA is stellar and her personality is just great; I love characters who tease other characters just for the hell of it.


Enjoyment: 10/10

It's even better than I remembered. I got absorbed and was never bored; there ususally is a point in each series where going gets tough for me before it becomes interesting again. Bakemonogatari just didn't. It was entertaining 100% of the time because of how non-standard it was. SHAFT really did a great job with the show.


Overall: 9.2/10 

I highly recommend it.

I'm still not too good at Reviews so feedback is appreciated. Anyways onto the review of my favorite season of one of my favorite anime series, the monogatari series.
Story:
*Read the synopsis for some info*
Now that you've read it. Lets go a bit more in depth without spoiling anything. Araragi koyomi throughout the series attempts to help those around him and they usually have Supernatural maladies/ oddities that have formed from within them whether it be from feelings or events. Throughout the story not only do you explore araragi and him as a character but also senjougahara, hachikuji, kanbaru, Hanekawa, nadeko and their struggles which somepeople while watching may relate to a feel a strong connection to. I sure know i did.


Art:

The Monogatari series definitely has some of my favorite character designs that do make them stand out. Not only are the characters good to look at but as well as some subtle scenes and environment shots. Also hitagi crab sure was experimental with its art and i quite liked it. (Watch hitagi crab and you'll know what i mean)


Sound:

I absolutely love Hiroshi kamiya's voice work and how great he delivers every line with araragi. With the comedy, to the great conversations. Hiroshi's voice is just perfect for araragi and how he is portrayed. I don't know much about the rest of the VA (I'm sorry lol) but they do an amazing job as well, i especially love senjougahara's VA. The rest of the cast is great too. Also the OP/END, and OST are good too


Characters:

Bakemonogatari's strong suit for sure. The characters i stated earlier are all explored through each arc and developed really well to the point where you would want to actually be there an interact with them. It's also so great to see each character interact with each other whether it be banter or some serious conversation. Also each character has a unique quirk to them which makes you distinguish them, makes you get some references outside of the anime like "sorry i stuttered". Notoriously one of the most known of the series. I definitely think every character is fleshed out pretty well. And attention is put to them when needed which is nice.


Enjoyment:

I can't recommend this anime enough, just go watch it if you Haven't. It's a great place to start with the monogatari series. Now what's there to enjoy? So much from the characters, to the stories that are told within each character and their background and how the Supernatural events actually have occurred. Also it's so satisfying watching the Supernatural events be resolved/dealt with and how each character goes about it. In sum, go watch, you won't regret it and you'll hopefully experience the same love that i do for this series
